articleContent.title: Chord: Dominant 7th in D# (Shape: D)
articleContent.content:
# Chord: Dominant 7th in D# (Shape: D)

## Description:
The dominant 7th chord in the key of D# (or Eb) features the notes D#-F#-A#-C#. It is also known as the D#7 or Eb7 chord. This chord is commonly used in various styles of music to create tension and movement due to its unstable nature within the tonal system.

## Notes and Intervals:
- D# (Root)
- F# (Major 3rd)
- A# (Perfect 5th)
- C# (Minor 7th)

## Musical Flavor:
The Dominant 7th chord in D# has a bold and bluesy sound due to the minor 7th interval. It creates a feeling of tension that resolves well to the tonic chord, making it a popular choice for adding movement and a sense of direction in music.

## Genre and Usage:
This chord is commonly used in jazz, blues, funk, and rock music genres. In jazz, it serves as a foundation for dominant chord progressions and improvisation. In blues and funk, it adds a gritty edge to the harmony. In rock music, the dominant 7th chord is often used to create a sense of drive and energy in songs.

## Songs:
Here are three songs that prominently feature the Dominant 7th chord in D#:
1. "Stormy Monday" by T-Bone Walker
2. "The Thrill Is Gone" by B.B. King
3. "Superstition" by Stevie Wonder
